answers.answerText: B. Epiretinal membrane with an intraretinal lesion
answers.explanation:
![](/content/media/paed_1_4.webp)

The OCT demonstrates an epiretinal membrane (blue arrow) causing traction and elevation of the underlying retina. The neurosensory retina on OCT, when correlated to the fundus photograph, seems to have a well demarcated mass (red arrows) with intraretinal disorganization; however, the retina nasal and temporal to the lesion has normal architecture. There is no subretinal fluid or hypo-reflective cavities suggestive of intraretinal fluid. PAMM typically presents as a hyper-reflective band within the inner retina.

questions.text: What findings are seen in the OCT macula above?

questions.title: Question 2
questions.text: Based on the history of NF2, fundus findings, and OCT macula imaging, what is the most likely diagnosis?

answers.answerText: D. Combined Hamartoma of the Retina and RPE
answers.explanation:
CHRRPE is a rare, benign tumour typically diagnosed in the pediatric population made of vascular tissue, glial cells and pigmented epithelial cells. Though the etiology is not yet known, a study by Pujari et al. surmised the lesion may arise from undifferentiated ectopic progenitor cells which failed to differentiate into RPE cells, ultimately accumulating within the retina. It is considered a hamartoma as this mature tissue is typically found within the retina and RPE, but grew in a disorganized manner. Clinically, CHRRPE is elevated with variable pigmentation and an overlying epiretinal membrane. They are typically found in the peripapillary region, but can also be found in the macula as in this case. There is a strong association with CHRRPE and NF2.

*References:*

1. Pujari A, Agarwal A, Chawla R et al. Congenital simple hamartoma of the retinal pigment epithelium: What is the probable cause? Med Hypotheses 2019; 123:79-80.
2. Kaye LD, Rothner AD, Beauchamp GR, Meyers SM, Estes ML. Ocular findings associated with neurofibromatosis type II. Ophthalmology. 1992 Sep;99(9):1424-9.

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text:
![](/content/media/paed_1_5.webp)

Looking back at the OCT macula, what sign is demonstrated by this combined hamartoma of the retina and RPE?

answers.explanation:
The Omega sign is a typical OCT finding for CHRRPEs. This retinal configuration is caused by the tumour pushing the outer plexiform posteriorly, while the epiretinal membrane causes an inward contraction of the neurosensory retina.

*References:*

1. Kumar V, Chawla R, Tripathy K. Omega Sign: A Distinct Optical Coherence Tomography Finding in Macular Combined Hamartoma of Retina and Retinal Pigment Epithelium. Ophthalmic Surg Lasers Imaging Retina. 2017 Feb 1;48(2):122-125.

answers.answerText: D. Disorganization of the Inner Retinal Layers

questions.title: Question 4
questions.text: What is the prognosis for CHRRPE lesions?

answers.answerText: A. Complete vision loss by age of 10
B. No change in vision over 10 years
C. Depends on location of lesion
answers.explanation:
The prognosis of CHRRPE has been demonstrated by Shields et al. in 2008 to be dependent on the location of the tumour. This study found that > 3 lines of Snellen visual acuity loss was seen in 60% of cases at 4 years with a macular CHRRPE, whereas only 13% had this level of acuity loss if presenting with an extra-macular tumour. The most crucial mainstay of treatment; however, is amblyopia treatment, as demonstrated by Schachat et al. in 1984. Regular monitoring every 6 months for potential complications, including epiretinal membrane progression, choroidal neovascularization, or macular holes should be conducted.

*References:*

1. Schachat AP, Shields JA, Fine SL, et al. Combined hamartomas of the retina and retinal pigment epithelium. Ophthalmology. 1984 Dec;91(12):1609-15.
2. Shields CL, Thangappan A, Hartzell K, Valente P, Pirondini C, Shields JA. Combined hamartoma of the retina and retinal pigment epithelium in 77 consecutive patients visual outcome based on macular versus extramacular tumor location. Ophthalmology. 2008 Dec;115(12):2246

answers.answerText: D. Improvement of vision over 10 years

title: Case 1
description: 11M presenting with painless vision loss OD for 2 years
patientPresentation:
A 11-year-old male with a history of neurofibromatosis type 2 presented to a pediatric retina clinic for assessment of an atypical lesion in his posterior pole OD. The patient’s mother noted a painless decrease in vision over the last 2 years, but denied trauma, flashes, floaters or a visual field deficit. The patient’s NF2 was stable; his previous MRI brain and orbits was unremarkable. Best corrected distance visual acuity was 20/80 OD and 20/20 OS. IOP was within normal limits, and there was no RAPD.
